title: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
description: This course covers the foundation knowledge of biochemistry and molecular biology through studying biochemical and cellular processes in the human body. Emphases will be placed on the metabolic pathways and their interrelationship. Gene regulation and expression, human genetic diseases, and recent biomedical advancements will also be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: • appreciate the structural-function relationship of biomolecules in human body;  • describe the metabolic pathways of carbohydrate, protein, lipid and nucleic acids in detail, and recall the holistic picture of different metabolisms and the way they interplay;  • understand the mechanisms of gene regulations in prokaryotes and eukaryotes; discuss various aspects of gene mutations and genetic diseases including those associated with metabolic disorders; and  • through topical studies cum presentation, discuss the latest advancements, controversial & ethical issues pertaining to biomedical sciences and researches.

title: Anatomy and Physiology I
description: This course provides a system-based review of the structures and functions, normal as well as abnormal, of basic tissues, blood and immune system, musculoskeletal system, cardiovascular system, respiratory system and gastrointestinal system. Emphases will be placed on those structures and functions that are relevant to common drug actions, and those that are affected by common drugs.

title: Clinical Microbiology and Infection Control
description: This course provides students with an introduction to microbiology and infectious diseases. Attention is focused on fundamental aspects of bacterial, fungal, and viral pathogenesis, therapy, control and prevention of infectious diseases. It also includes the basics of hospital infection and control in preventing spread of infection and protecting oneself from infection in the workplace.
outcome: 1. Describe the fundamental aspects of microbiology (including but not limited to): cell structure and classification of microorganisms, isolation of microorganism, susceptibility testing and mechanisms of resistance 2. Recognize and discuss the pathogenesis, clinical manifestations, epidemiology, treatment and prevention of infections caused by gram-positive and gram negative bacteria and other microorganisms 3. Discuss the role of pharmacists in management of infectious diseases and utilization of antimicrobial agents 4. To understand the basis of hospital infection and control, in preventing spread of infection and protecting oneself from infection at workplace.

Illustrate the role of molecular modification in the development of new drugs  4. Relate chemical structure to biological availability, biological activity and routes of delivery/metabolism for drugs from selected drug classes

title: Principles of Pharmaceutical Dispensing
description: This course provides an overview of the pharmaceutical dispensing practice as it relates to the interpretation and assessment of prescriptions and the formulation and preparation of medications for administration and use of the patient. Appropriate dispensing of medications requires the combined knowledge of the physico-chemical aspects of each medication along with practical issues as it relates to the individual patient. The course will also emphasize the various dosage forms and its implications for use, the preparation and appropriate handling of sterile dosage forms such as parenteral products, cytotoxic drugs and parenteral nutrition and practical issues associated with the use of medications.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students should be able to: 1. Demonstrate basic understanding of the prescription preparation process and how various dosage forms and the resultant preparation may be safely and appropriately used by a patient 2. Describe the range of pharmaceutical formulations, their routes of administration and the advantages and disadvantages of each 3. Perform basic pharmaceutical calculations necessary to further evaluate safety and efficacy of treatment 4. Describe the significance of sterile dosage form preparation as well as the risk and benefits of using aseptic techniques 5. Know the differences between the various types of needles, syringes, and parenteral products. 6. Demonstrate proficiency in implementing aseptic technique when handling sterile preparations, cytotoxic drugs and Total Parenteral Nutrition. 7. Describe appropriate measure of handling medication and medical wastes 8. Describe the role of compounding in optimizing patient outcomes and demonstrate knowledge in preparing medications extemporaneously 9. Demonstrate good research and analytical skills 10. Develop good oral presentation skills
syllabus: Prescription, Rx Labeling, Dispensing Process Sources of Information Pharmaceutical Dosage Forms + Routes of Adminstration Oral Liquid Dosage Forms Topical Dosage Forms Inhalational Devices Cytotoxic Drugs

title: Community Pharmacy Summer Clerkship
description: This course is intended for students who choose research as an area of concentration in the final year. It consists of one week of clerkship training completed in the summer term before the final year under the supervision of a community pharmacist. Students will gain knowledge and experience in the operational aspects of the pharmacy and participate in the professional services.

title: Hospital Pharmacy Summer Clerkship
description: This course is an elective clerkship consisting of one week clinical pharmacy clerkship training in the hospital setting. It is intended for students who choose research as an area of concentration in the final year. This clerkship provides an overview of the role and function of pharmacist in the hospital pharmacy practice setting. During the clerkship experience, students will participate in activities include ward rounding, communication with other healthcare professionals, provision of drug information to patients and other healthcare providers, participation in the choice, dosing and monitoring of drugs for individual patients to optimize efficacy, safety and cost-effectiveness.

title: Clinical Assessment and Monitoring
description: PHAR3812 is the preparatory course prior to the clinical clerkship or the pharmacy students at the Prince of Wales Hospital. It allows pharmacy students to experience patient-focused pharmacy practice. The emphasis of this clerkship is to provide quality training to clerkship students in the internal medicine ward. This will allow students to have more hand-on experience outside the typical classroom. Activities of the clerkship include daily pharmacy rounding in internal medicine, communication with other healthcare professionals, participation in the choice, dosing, and monitoring of drugs for individual patients to optimise efficacy, safety, and cost-effectiveness during daily case discussion with preceptor. Due to the nature of the clinical pharmacy clerkship, the preparatory course is designed to prepare the students for the upcoming clinical pharmacy clerkship. The main targeted areas in PHAR 3812 include literature evaluation, drug information, clinical assessment & monitoring, patient data documentation, medical chart review, written as well as oral case presentations.
outcome: • Write coherently and concisely and speak comprehensibly at the outset of the clerkship; • Read basic chart notes from a variety of healthcare providers and have a basic knowledge of the common disease states encountered in the acute care settings; • Be able to critique a medical journal; • Understand the basic concepts of fluid and nutrition; • Be able to accurately obtain medication-related information from a MAR; • Be able to present a comprehensive patient case (e.g., chief complaint, history of present illness, medical, social, and medication history, diagnostic/lab test results, physical findings, assessment and plan); • Be able to identify and appropriately utilise drug information resources to assist with patient-specific drug therapy monitoring; • Be able to retrieve accurate laboratory test results and vital signs for any given patient; • Be able to identify the contents of each portion of the medical record; • Be organised and have developed a system for recording/memorising patient-specific information (e.g., height, weight, allergies, diagnoses, medications, lab values, and subjective complaints).
syllabus: 1. Medical chart documentation 2. Professional communication skills 3. Literature evaluation 4. Basic concepts of fluid and nutrition 5. Drug information techniques 6. ECGs reading and common arrhythmia management

title: Hospital Pharmacy Clerkship

description: This is a three-week hospital practice rotation at a public or private hospital. The purpose of this rotation is to provide exposure to our fourth year undergraduate pharmacy students on pharmacy practice, pharmacy operation in the hospital setting and some clinical service(s), if available, outside the typical classroom. title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Cardiology
description: The clinical clerkship is a minimum of 3-week clerkship for the pharmacy students at the Prince of Wales Hospital. It allows pharmacy students to experience patient-focused pharmacy practice. The emphasis of this clerkship is to provide quality training to clerkship students in the cardiology ward. This will allow students to have more hand-on experience outside the typical classroom. Activities of the clerkship include daily pharmacy rounding, communication with other healthcare professionals, participation in the choice, dosing, and monitoring of drugs for individual patients to optimise efficacy, safety, and cost-effectiveness during daily case discussion with preceptor and the hospital pharmacy rotation. This is a higher level of training that requires higher expectations and levels of responsibility. As a student pharmacist in the clinical clerkship, you are expected to be hardworking and dedicated. You will be dealing with patient lives and some of the most prestigious cardiologists in Hong Kong.

title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Infectious Diseases
description: This course is an elective clerkship at the hospital. The focus is on the purulent use of antimicrobial therapy according to institutional guidelines. The course also emphasizes the clinical techniques to apply pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of antimicrobials in patient care. The up-to-date treatment guidelines of infectious diseases will be discussed.

title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Psychiatry
description: This elective clerkship provides students with exposure to patient care and pharmacy practice in psychiatry. The clerkship learning activities include ward rounding, patient interviewing, communicating with other health-care professionals, reviewing of psychiatric regimen and providing drug information to patients and other health-care providers.

syllabus: • Introduction to Psychiatric Pharmacy Clerkship • Anxiety disorder • Depression  • Schizophrenia • Bipolar disorder • Patient Interviewing and Counselling

title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Oncology
description: This course is an elective clerkship providing an introduction to the pharmacological management of various hematological malignanies, namely leukemia, lymphoma, multiple myeloma, and autologous stem cell transplant. Students will participate in ward rounds with hematology oncologists, as well as shadow in the hematology outpatient clinic. Students will learn about disease pathology, symptomology, diagnostic parameters, and drug monitoring parameters through patient case discussion. Other topics including oncology supportive care, antimicrobial prophylaxis, and pain control will also be covered.

description: This course is an elective clerkship which introduces hospital pharmacy practice and clinical pharmacy services in various research and teaching hospitals in mainland China. Specialties involved in the training include cardiology, general internal medicine, and critical care medicine. description: The course is an elective clerkship which focuses on the research and practice in Traditional Chinese Medicine related areas such as rotations in TCM clinics, guidance on proper usage of herbal/TCM medicines and evaluation of potential herb-drug interactions.

title: Drug Information Clerkship
description: The Drug Information Clerkship is a clinical clerkship rotation designed to provide students with practical training to further develop drug information skills. Drug information involves not only the literature evaluation of evidence based information but also drug education and identification of adverse drug events to ensure patient safety. Building upon the knowledge of the different references, students will learn techniques that will enhance their proficiency in information search and critical assessment skills. Verbal and written communication skills are crucial in drug information in order for such information to be disseminated effectively. To emphasize these areas, students are expected to communicate with patients through drug counseling, with the public by conducting educational programs, and with other health care professionals and colleagues during therapeutic use evaluation. Utilizing the School of Pharmacy’s On-Line Drug-Enquiry Platform (AMPOULE), the clerkship exposes students to the many different types of questions from real patients who expect high quality and professional advice.

title: Graduation Project II
requirements: For students in Master of Clinical Pharmacy; Prerequisite: PHAR5824
description: This course consists of independent and teamwork with supervision. Students are required to implement a predetermined practice-based project of interest in their work settings. The project should demonstrate pharmacists' impact on patient care, pharmaceutical research and development or administrative management. Students are expected to be involved in project implementation, outcome measurement, result analysis, report writing and presentation. Pre-requisite: PHAR5824.
outcome: Upon completion of the project, students should be able to • Implement a practice-based project that can demonstrate pharmacist’s impact on patient care, teaching, pharmaceutical research and development or administrative management • Demonstrate application of knowledge and motivation to learn • Identify potential obstacles in conducting a project and formulate strategies to solve them accordingly • Non-verbally and verbally communicate effectively as demonstrated by written reports and oral presentation of project • Be flexible and adaptive to unforeseen circumstances and strive to take alternative approaches in different situations • Demonstrate ability in working as a team and good interpersonal skills • Demonstrate good time-management skills and logical organization of tasks • Develop working knowledge on computer software commonly used for data analysis
